docs.lead_paragraph: Two strikingly different pictures of Tabitha Walrond were drawn yesterday in opening statements at her trial on charges of second-degree manslaughter in the starvation death of the infant son she had been breast-feeding. Robert Holdman, an assistant district attorney, depicted Ms. Walrond, 21, as a woman scorned, so angry at the father of her child for taking a new girlfriend that she wanted an abortion, tried to shut the baby's paternal relatives out of his life, and let her son starve to death at 2 months, on Aug. 27, 1997.

headline.main: Trial Begins for Mother in Breast-Fed Infant's Starvation Death

docs.abstract: Trial of Tabitha Walrond on charges of second-degree manslaughter in starvation death of infant son she had been breast-feeding begins, Bronx; opening statements noted; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 200 teachers and students, carrying signs with ''Justice for Kathy'' in red letters, rallied outside a school board meeting tonight in support of a teacher who says she is being denied tenure because she got pregnant. The teacher, Kathleen V. Williamsen, said in an interview earlier today that her fellow high school teachers had warned her: the principal at Elmont Memorial hates the disruption caused when young teachers leave classes in midyear, hates scrambling to find qualified substitutes, hates how teachers-turned-mothers no longer stay after school for hours giving extra help or supervising student activities.

headline.main: Show of Support for Teacher Who Says Pregnancy Blocked Tenure Bid

docs.abstract: More than 200 teachers and students rally outside school board meeting in Elmont, NY, in support of Kathleen V Williamsen, teacher who says she is being denied tenure at Elmont Memorial school because she got pregnant; principle Diane Scricca refuses comment; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR only the fourth time in its 57-year history, the Advertising Council has a new president. The council, the nonprofit organization that has coordinated public service campaigns for Madison Avenue since 1942, is naming Peggy Conlon as president, succeeding Ruth A. Wooden, effective June 1. Ms. Wooden announced in January that she would leave the council, which is based in New York, after serving as president since November 1987.

headline.main: The Advertising Council's new president is the first one to come from the media business.

docs.lead_paragraph: An overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but the public's questions, doubts and fears. ''Just because we're doctors doesn't mean we don't also look at the Internet,'' said Dr. Bruce G. Gellin of Vanderbilt University, staff director of the Vaccine Initiative, a special project of the Infectious Diseases Society of America. Some Web sites about immunization, he said, ''focus to a large degree on concerns about safety that are far more hypothesis than fact.''
docs.abstract: Overload of conflicting and often alarmist information about vaccinations is leading some medical experts into a new field of research: not the effectiveness and safety of vaccines, which they consider proven, but public's questions, doubts and fears; Infectious Diseases Society of America has created initiative, which is using focus groups, surveys and other marketing tools to explain immunization to public; doctors fight backlash over vaccines (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. I am just beginning a job search, and I've already been asked twice in interviews whether I am married, have children or plan to have children. While my answers to the first two questions are yes and no, I have dodged the third, for fear that any child-bearing plans might cost me a new job. Is it true that employers aren't supposed to ask? How should I handle it when they do? A. A job hunt is tough enough without having to dance around uncomfortable -- and, yes, illegal -- interview questions.
docs.abstract: Michelle Cottle Working column advises on handling personal questions asked at job interview (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: www.babycenter.com BABYCENTER is one of the heavyweight sites in the new-parent market. A quick look makes it clear that the site has attracted significant sponsorship from companies selling everything from cotton swabs to life insurance. Indeed, at first glance it was hard to tell whether the Web site was just a catalogue for baby products or a genuine source of general information for parents. So it was a relief to see a link to a page for expectant parents asking, ''What gear do you really need?'' Here, the implication seemed to be, was advice that would allow a neophyte, budget-conscious parent to cut through the hype and buy only what was really needed.
docs.abstract: Eric Nagourney assesses Babycenter, Web site for new parents; photo (M)
